title: APRA urges more capital be held against NZ banks
text:
The prudential regulator said major banks with large exposures to subsidiaries in New Zealand will need to hold more capital in Australia to protect domestic depositors.

ANZ Banking Group, which has the largest operation in New Zealand, told the ASX is analysing the impact of the move.

The ultimate impact from APRA's policy change on banks will depend on how they respond to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand’s intention to significantly increase capital levels in NZ to protect its economy. RBNZ is planning on publishing its final requirements later in the year.

APRA said on Tuesday it is proposing to limit the amount of the exposure to an individual subsidiary that a bank can leverage (meaning the group in Australia does not to hold dollar-for-dollar capital at the parent company level) to 10 per cent of a bank’s CET1 capital.

“These proposed measures seek to support the resilience of the major banks' Australian operations,” APRA deputy chair John Lonsdale said in a statement.

“In relation to New Zealand, there are a number of options available to the banks. If they decide to fund any higher capital requirements by retaining local profits, they are unlikely to require additional capital domestically."
description: ANZ said it is reviewing a policy change from APRA designed to protect depositors in Australia from NZ lending.
